desc: Any living being, like an animal or person.
example: The forest is full of strange creatures.

desc: A fully grown person or animal.
example: Children must be accompanied by an adult.

desc: A person who is 100 years old or older.
example: The centenarian shared stories from her childhood.

desc: A very young baby.
example: The infant slept peacefully in the crib.

desc: A young child learning to walk.
example: The toddler took her first steps today.

desc: Old or aging, usually about people.
example: The bus has special seats for elderly passengers.

desc: A young person aged between 13 and 19.
example: Teens often enjoy listening to music and hanging out with friends.

desc: To be raised or taken care of by someone.
example: He was brought up by his grandparents.

desc: To leave your country to live in another.
example: Many people emigrated from Europe in the 19th century.

desc: To come to a new country to live there.
example: They immigrated to Canada for better opportunities.

desc: To legally end a marriage.
example: They decided to get divorced after five years of marriage.

desc: To promise to marry someone.
example: They got engaged on their holiday in Paris.

desc: To become husband and wife.
example: They got married in a beautiful garden ceremony.

desc: To receive money or property from someone after they die.
example: She inherited her grandmother’s house.

desc: A polite way to say someone has died.
example: Her uncle passed away last year.

desc: To stop working, usually because of age.
example: My father plans to retire at 65.

desc: To start living a stable and calm life.
example: They moved to the countryside to settle down.

desc: To end a relationship or partnership.
example: The band split up after ten years.

desc: To end a romantic relationship.
example: They broke up after a big argument.

desc: Rules made by the government to keep order.
example: Everyone must follow the law.

desc: To have something as your property.
example: They own a house by the lake.

desc: To start loving someone deeply.
example: They fell in love at university.

desc: To become an adult or mature.
example: He wants to be a pilot when he grows up.

desc: A group of people born around the same time.
example: Each generation has different values.

desc: Finally, after some time or effort.
example: He eventually finished writing the book.

desc: Family members from a long time ago.
example: Our ancestors came from this village.

desc: Help customers in a shop by providing goods or services.
example: He served customers at the bakery.

desc: Family members who come after you, like children or grandchildren.
example: She wants to leave a legacy for her descendants.

desc: A series of things in a specific order.
example: The movie had a confusing sequence of events.

desc: Something that happens, often important or unusual.
example: The concert was the biggest event of the year.

desc: A part of a play, movie, or story.
example: The final scene was very emotional.

desc: To stop someone while they are speaking or doing something.
example: Please don’t interrupt when I’m speaking.

desc: A person who delivers or processes mail.
example: The postal worker brought the package this morning.

desc: To give off light or make something bright.
example: The sun was shining brightly.

desc: To make something larger in amount, size, or number.
example: They want to increase the number of staff.

desc: To make something smaller in amount, size, or number.
example: The price decreased after the holiday season.

desc: Food that is eaten at a specific time of the day.
example: Dinner is the main meal of the day for many people.

desc: Nearly, but not completely.
example: I almost missed the train this morning.

desc: To stop being visible or to go away.
example: The magician made the rabbit disappear.

desc: To say that someone is responsible for something bad.
example: Don't blame me if you’re late!

desc: Unable to stop doing or using something harmful.
example: He’s addicted to video games.

desc: A small, flat pill or an electronic device.
example: She took a tablet for her headache.

desc: Discussions or disagreements, often heated.
example: They often have arguments about money.

desc: A machine or tool made for a specific purpose.
example: This device helps measure heart rate.

desc: The ability to use or enter something.
example: You need a password to access the system.

desc: An idea or explanation based on study or thought.
example: The theory was tested in many experiments.

desc: To talk informally with someone.
example: Let’s chat over coffee later.

desc: To guide or be in charge of something.
example: She will lead the project team.

desc: Saying that someone has done something wrong.
example: He gave her an accusing look.

desc: Acting in a way that may hurt or upset others.
example: The dog became aggressive when provoked.

desc: Thinking you are better than others.
example: He sounded arrogant during the interview.

desc: Feeling angry or hurt for a long time.
example: She felt bitter about the unfair decision.

desc: Peaceful and not easily upset.
example: He stayed calm during the emergency.

desc: Saying nice things about someone.
example: She was very complimentary about your work.

desc: Feeling or showing thankfulness.
example: I’m grateful for your help.

desc: Unhappy or in a very bad state.
example: He looked miserable after the breakup.

desc: Feeling a longing for the past.
example: The song made her feel nostalgic.

desc: Expecting the best possible outcome.
example: She’s optimistic about her exam results.

desc: Expecting the worst possible outcome.
example: He’s too pessimistic about the future.

desc: Using irony to mock or convey contempt.
example: She made a sarcastic comment about his cooking.

desc: Showing compassion or understanding towards others.
example: She was very sympathetic when I lost my job.

desc: Requiring immediate action or attention.
example: This is an urgent matter that needs solving today.

desc: A statement or event that serves to alert about potential danger or harm.
example: They gave a warning about the storm.

desc: Guidance or recommendations given to someone.
example: He gave me some good advice about studying.

desc: To influence someone to believe or do something.
example: I persuaded her to come to the party.

desc: To be present at an event or activity.
example: Over 100 people attended the meeting.

desc: A gathering of people who have not seen each other for a long time.
example: We had a class reunion after 10 years.

desc: To close something forcefully or securely.
example: Please shut the door behind you.

desc: To express approval or admiration for someone or something.
example: The teacher praised the students for their work.

desc: To stop something from happening or occurring.
example: Washing hands can prevent illness.

desc: To spend a long time doing something.
example: She spent ages getting ready for the party.

desc: A mistake or responsibility for something bad.
example: It was my fault we were late.

desc: Behaving badly or not following rules.
example: The naughty child refused to do his homework.

desc: To stop doing something as you get older.
example: She grew out of her fear of the dark.

desc: Very rarely.
example: I hardly ever eat fast food.

desc: A place or equipment for a particular activity.
example: The sports facility is open 24 hours.

en: to get on well with someone
desc: To have a good relationship with someone.
example: She gets on well with her classmates.

desc: A set of clothing, typically for sports or exercise.
example: He wore a blue tracksuit to the gym.

desc: A winter sport involving sliding down snow-covered slopes on skis.
example: They went skiing in the Alps.

desc: Uncommon or out of the ordinary.
example: It’s unusual to see snow in April here.

desc: Without a doubt, in a clear and obvious way.
example: She will certainly pass the test.

desc: To meet or exceed expectations.
example: The movie didn’t live up to my expectations.

desc: In the direction opposite to where you are facing.
example: He fell backwards off the chair.

desc: The way someone or something looks.
example: Her appearance changed a lot after college.

desc: To leave someone, especially in a relationship.
example: He walked out on his family.

desc: A place where elderly people are cared for.
example: She moved into a nursing home last year.

desc: To be compatible or in agreement with.
example: He doesn’t fit in with the new team.

desc: People who live in a particular place or community.
example: The residents of the town are very friendly.

desc: To have a good relationship with someone.
example: He gets on with his boss really well.

desc: In spite of something.
example: Despite the rain, we went hiking.

desc: To lose contact with someone.
example: We lost touch after school.

desc: To maintain contact with someone.
example: I try to keep in touch with old friends.

desc: To register or enroll for something.
example: I signed up for a language course.

desc: To meet or talk to someone after a long time.
example: Let’s catch up with each other soon.

desc: To carry out a plan or promise.
example: He went through with the plan despite doubts.

desc: To tolerate or endure something unpleasant.
example: I can't put up with this noise anymore.

desc: To no longer have something.
example: We ran out of milk this morning.

desc: To leave someone or something behind.
example: The soldier abandoned his post.

desc: To provide or make available.
example: They supply water to the whole region.

desc: To arrive at a particular point or place.
example: We reached the mountain peak at noon.

desc: To endure or accept something, even if unpleasant.
example: She can’t tolerate loud noises.

desc: To search for information.
example: I looked up the word in the dictionary.

desc: To respect or admire someone.
example: He looks up to his older brother.

desc: To escape from a place or situation.
example: The thief got away before the police arrived.

desc: To escape without being caught.
example: He cheated on the test and got away with it.

desc: To invent a story or excuse.
example: She made up an excuse for being late.

desc: To compensate for something lost or missed.
example: He made up for being late by helping clean up.

desc: To rise from a lying or sitting position.
example: I usually get up at 7 a.m.

desc: To engage in an activity or behavior, often secretive or mischievous.
example: What did you get up to last weekend?

desc: To enter a place.
example: She went in and closed the door behind her.

desc: To participate in a particular activity.
example: He goes in for swimming competitions.

desc: To return to a previous place.
example: She went back to her hometown after many years.

desc: To fail to keep a promise or agreement.
example: Don’t go back on your word.

desc: A feeling of unhappiness or dissatisfaction.
example: Failing the test was a big disappointment.

desc: To respect or hold someone in high regard.
example: I admire her dedication and hard work.

desc: A set of three related works, often books or movies.
example: I watched the entire trilogy over the weekend.

desc: A large amount of wealth.
example: She inherited a fortune from her uncle.

desc: A person who commits theft, often in a home or building.
example: The burglar broke in through the window.

desc: A system of self-defense or combat techniques.
example: He has practiced martial arts since he was a child.

desc: To be able to do something.
example: I managed to finish all my homework on time.

desc: To meet or find something unexpectedly.
example: I came across an old photo album in the attic.

desc: Able to be separated.
example: The two parts are easily separable.

desc: Unable to be separated.
example: The twins were inseparable as children.

desc: A crime of stealing from a place, especially by force.
example: There was a robbery at the bank last night.

desc: Impolite or disrespectful behavior.
example: It’s rude to interrupt someone while they’re speaking.

desc: A period of life between childhood and adulthood when a person undergoes physical and emotional changes.
example: Adolescence is often a challenging time.

desc: A person in the period of adolescence.
example: The school has a program to support adolescents.

desc: To manage or handle a situation or problem.
example: She knows how to deal with stress.

desc: Happening very quickly or at a high speed.
example: There was a rapid change in temperature.

desc: Relying on others for support or resources.
example: He is still financially dependent on his parents.

desc: The state of being free to make choices or decisions.
example: They fought for their freedom.

desc: The right to keep personal information private.
example: I need some privacy to make a call.

desc: To feel angry or bitter towards someone because of something they did.
example: He resents his boss for not giving him a raise.

desc: The likelihood or chance of something happening.
example: The odds of winning the lottery are low.

desc: The process of losing something.
example: She felt deep sorrow over the loss of her dog.

desc: To refuse to accept or consider something or someone.
example: He rejected the job offer.

desc: To act in a certain way, especially in a particular situation.
example: Children should behave in class.

desc: In a way that shows responsibility or accountability.
example: She spends her money responsibly.

desc: A feeling of worry or interest about something.
example: There is growing concern about climate change.

desc: A feeling of anger or displeasure.
example: Her constant talking was a source of irritation.

desc: Having a lack of trust or belief in someone or something.
example: He was distrustful of their intentions.

ru: Быть в хороших/плохих отношениях с кем-то
en: to be on good/bad terms with someone
pron: /tuː bi ɒn ɡʊd/bæd tɜːmz wɪð ˈsʌmwʌn/
desc: To have a good or bad relationship with someone.
example: She’s on good terms with her neighbors.

desc: Limits or rules that are set for behavior or actions.
example: Setting clear boundaries is important in relationships.

desc: A person or thing that causes inconvenience or annoyance.
example: That noisy dog is a real nuisance.

desc: The physical or mental energy needed to do something.
example: You need to make more effort in your studies.

desc: To have a natural tendency or habit of doing something.
example: She tends to be late for meetings.

desc: A personal record of thoughts or events, usually kept private.
example: He writes in his diary every night.

desc: At the present moment.
example: She is currently studying in London.

desc: The state of being well-known or recognized by many people.
example: The actor rose to fame after his first movie.
